posts.name:
Matt Rocha
Matt Rocha
posts.content:
I routinely check my spam and respond to bad emails on occasion. 

What is alarming to me is the amount of technical or technical persona focused solutions that are selling poorly via emails that land in spam and have zero thought of what to say to THE HARDEST persona group you can target (Eng/IT leaders)

It’s a bunch of low effort garbage. That’s the bar.

If you’re selling to this group you have to come correct.

If you’re selling poorly to this group, you’re playing the game on hard mode, with a blind fold, and a banana with electrodes barely attached to it as a controller.

You will go out of business unless your solution basically sells itself or you have someone that actually knows what they’re doing working there.

posts.name:
Jeff Roberts
Jeff Roberts
posts.content:
AI in Hiring—Opportunity or Obstacle?

A recent NBC News article highlights how AI is reshaping the hiring process, streamlining applications and helping companies manage massive volumes of resumes. It sounds like a win-win: faster hiring for employers and easier applications for job seekers. But here's the catch—it might also be unintentionally creating new barriers.

The article explores concerns about bias and the over-reliance on algorithms, which could leave qualified candidates overlooked. It's a reminder that while AI can bring efficiency, we can't lose sight of fairness and the human side of hiring.

This sparks an important question: As AI takes on more roles in recruitment, how do we ensure it supports fairness in hiring rather than undermining it?

Read more on NBC News:

comments.commentText:
It's not streamlining anything. Utilizing AI just forces candidates to adjust and "play the game". They'll start slipping in the key words that AI is set to look for in a partciular role, and now you're right back to square 1 of heating out all the smelt to get to the ore.

In my last job search I was specifically referred to apply for a role by an internal employee of that company, and their HR recruiter for that particular role told me he had to go manually look for my resume because the AI filtering rejected my application.

That should tell you everything you need to know about how "useful" it is.

It's a strange scenario that HR is using AI to find humans to create agents that replace humans to do work. Jeff Roberts

Used properly, AI can augment humans by better sorting candidates than a human can. So, some of those hacks are removed.

The end result will only matter if the code is designed to find the right candidate rather than the one that looks best. I have personally worked with some ding dongs that came from the finest MBA programs in the world.

posts.name:
Steve Litzow
Steve Litzow
posts.content:
Big deal about to close... but it’s not the ICP?

When I work on refining sales strategies for scale ups, I always include a validation step.

It comes after the proposal and negotiation.

It’s an internal step for:
– The CEO or VP of Sales to review the deal.
– The SDR or sales manager to self-analyze.
– An item to discuss during weekly or monthly deal reviews.

The key focus of validation?

Double-check the customer still fits your ICP.

It’s overlooked because:
– The SDR wants to hit quota.
– The sales manager wants to hit quota.
– Or simply, the revenue is too tempting to resist.

But if you’re serious about scaling to 8 or 9 figures, you must take this step.

You must reconsider going ahead if the ICP isn’t the right fit.

Here’s why…

I recently read a story from Jake Fuentes, co-founder of Cascade, about why he shut his startup down.

He admitted that “ICP fray” was a key factor.

Cascade initially defined their ICP as “nontechnical business analysts using Excel to crunch big data sets”.

The definition was too broad.

They ended up chasing customers with wildly different use cases:
– A scooter company managing location data.
– An HR team managing employee data.

They didn’t have a framework to accept or reject opportunities, so they tried to support them all.

Jake described this as “a slow death of a thousand cuts.”

Supporting anyone and everyone pulled the company in a million directions, ultimately diluting their focus and stunting growth.

If you want to scale successfully, rejecting deals from prospects who don’t fit your ICP is the tough but necessary way forward.

Validate every deal.

Stick to your guns.

Keep closing.

Like what you read? ️ Repost it to your network and follow Steve Litzow for more.

Want to accelerate your sales? Join our community of CEOs & Sales Leaders subscribers today:

comments.commentText: Staying true to your ICP is crucial for growth. Misaligned deals might boost short-term revenue but often lead to inefficiencies and lost focus. Discipline here pays dividends!

posts.name:
Bailey Spell
Bailey Spell
posts.content: Silicon Valley is a crazy place. Crazy ambitious people, you live 1-2 years in the future, self-driving cars. But the most underrated part about this place is the willingness of people to help you without anything in return. It's amazing.and I came here knowing no one, and after being here for >1.5 years, we have received countless help, insight, and support from many people who had nothing to gain. This is one of the many magical secrets to the success of Silicon Valley and why nowhere else in the world can recreate this.

posts.name:
Rutul Vadadoriya
Rutul Vadadoriya
posts.content:
I’ve always asked myself: What if I can’t make my clients happy?

What if the real estate market is too hard to predict?

What if I fail because of these doubts?

I could think of 100 reasons to give up.

But you know what? Success happens when you take action.

I once read, "You only lose when you stop trying." That stayed with me.

Still, I kept doubting myself.
"Oh, I might not close this deal."

Did I really try to connect with my client?
"Oh, this market might not work for me."

Did I spend time planning and thinking?
The other day, I looked back at my real estate work.

I saw how much I’ve done—every sale, every happy client.

It made me realize none of it happened fast. It took effort, step by step.

Would I have made it this far if I didn’t take action? No.

For you, it might be different. But don’t let doubts stop you.

Use them to move forward.

It might be hard, but what if it works out?

You can do this.

comments.commentText: Doubts are natural, but taking action makes all the difference. Love this mindset!

How to get started in Marketing without spending a Dime ($0)

When I decided to pursue marketing, I had zero experience and no budget to pay for expensive courses. I remember sitting in my room, scrolling endlessly, wondering, How do I even start?

That’s when I stumbled upon free resources that didn’t just teach me the basics, they gave me the confidence to land my first freelance client.

Fast forward to today, I’ve built communities of 20,000+, led successful campaigns that led to over 100,000+ downloads in less than 48 hours and mentored aspiring marketers. All thanks to resources like these that gave me my foundation.

As your Marketing Big sister , I want you to have the same head start I did. Here are some amazing, FREE marketing courses you can start today:

 Content Marketing Certification – Learn how to create, promote, and analyze content like a pro.


 Social Media Marketing Certification – Master strategies for platforms like LinkedIn, Instagram, and more.


 Email Marketing Certification – Craft emails that convert and engage.


 Inbound Marketing Certification – Learn to attract customers through value-driven content.


 Affiliate Marketing by Ahrefs – Dive into affiliate marketing strategies.


 Marketing Course by edX – Explore comprehensive marketing topics.


These courses don’t just teach skills they build confidence, open doors, and set you up for success. Plus, you will also be getting a free certificate after taking these courses.

If you’ve been waiting for a sign to start your marketing journey, this is it because let’s be honest, Netflix isn’t adding ‘Certified Marketer’ to your resume, so get to Work

Let me know which course you’ll be taking first—I’m here to cheer you on

Seeing me for the first time? I'm, a Growth Marketer seeking to empower young/aspiring professionals in their professional journey by sharing my personal journey and resources like courses, mentorships, Job vacancies to those seeking global opportunities. Welcome to my world

posts.name:
Jodie Cook
Jodie Cook
posts.content:
To make money while you sleep:

Do the work while you’re awake

Everyone dreams of making endless passive income, but few know how to make it happen.

These ChatGPT prompts will help create digital products that keep going long after you log off.

Step 1. Open ChatGPT

Step 2. Work through the prompts:

- Create your digital product
- Build your sales system
- Set up multiple streams
- Price for profit
- Scale what works

Step 3. Transform your expertise into income streams that work while you rest.

The sooner you begin, the sooner you earn.

comments.commentText: Smart strategy—start small, scale big. ChatGPT makes passive income planning so accessible!
